metadata.title: Convert PSI to Bar – Pressure Converter
metadata.description: Convert pressure from PSI (Pounds per Square Inch) to Bar, essential for pressure equipment and tire specifications.

introduction: This converter transforms pressure from PSI to Bar, enabling translation between American and metric pressure units.
PSI is commonly used in North America for pressure ratings (tires, hydraulics, air compressors), while bar is the metric standard.
This converter uses the standard relationship where 1 bar equals approximately 14.5038 PSI.
methodology: 1 PSI = 0.0689476 bar. 1 bar = 14.5038 PSI. To convert PSI to bar, multiply by 0.0689476.
Tire pressure is typically specified in PSI in North America but bar in other regions. Understanding both helps with equipment specifications.
Hydraulic systems often mix measurement units depending on where equipment is made. Converting is essential for safety.
This converter provides precise pressure conversions for equipment maintenance.
examples: Example 1 – Tire pressure: A car tire rated at 32 PSI equals approximately 2.2 bar.
Example 2 – Compressor: An air compressor rated at 100 PSI produces approximately 6.9 bar pressure.
Example 3 – Hydraulic system: A 1,000 PSI rating equals approximately 69 bar.

faqs.question: What is the conversion from PSI to Bar?
faqs.answer: 1 PSI ≈ 0.0689476 bar. Multiply PSI by 0.0689476 to get bar.

faqs.question: What is the difference between PSI and bar?
faqs.answer: PSI is Pounds per Square Inch (imperial). Bar is a metric pressure unit. 1 bar ≈ 14.5 PSI.

faqs.question: Why are both units still used?
faqs.answer: PSI is standard in North America while bar is used internationally. Equipment from different regions uses different units.

glossary.definition: Pounds per Square Inch, imperial unit of pressure.
Metric unit of pressure equal to 100,000 pascals.
